byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

abstract: Materials that terrorists could use to make nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain vulnerable around world as Pres Obama's final Nuclear Security Summit approaches, despite his six-year effort to corral loose material; many countries have remained resistant to safeguards, with Pakistan, China, India and Japan planning new nuclear facilities, while Russian Pres Vladimir Putin will boycott summit; vulnerability of Belgium's nuclear plants and intent of Islamic State are of serious concern.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama gathers leaders for his last Nuclear Security Summit, tons of materials that terrorists could use to make small nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain vulnerable to theft.

headline.main: As Nuclear Security Summit Begins, Materials Remain Vulnerable to Theft
headline.print_headline: Nuclear Fuels Are Vulnerable Despite a Push

snippet: As President Obama gathers leaders for his last Nuclear Security Summit, tons of materials that terrorists could use to make small nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain vulnerable to theft.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
